image.altText: Smoke rises from buildings.

items.synopsis: Israel's military says at least 26 soldiers have been killed in the attack by Hamas on the country's south, adding to the national death toll of more than 250, according to Israeli media. Follow live.

title.children: Israel's security forces target homes of Hamas leaders after attacks leave more than 250 dead

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Israeli embassy to the United States has released figures on the casualties suffered by Israel during the weekend assault by Hamas, including how many civilians and soldiers have been kidnapped. The latest figures reported by Palestinian health officials say 256 civilians have been killed in subsequent strikes by Israel, including 20 children. They also report nearly 1,800 people have been wounded. Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel says 100 of its civilians and soldiers have been kidnapped

children.content: The Israeli embassy to the United States has released figures on the casualties suffered by Israel during the weekend assault by Hamas, including how many civilians and soldiers have been kidnapped.
The latest figures reported by Palestinian health officials say 256 civilians have been killed in subsequent strikes by Israel, including 20 children.
They also report nearly 1,800 people have been wounded.
Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Israeli military said it was still fighting Hamas incursions in eight places on Sunday morning, according to reports by the AP. Meanwhile, Reuters reported a statement from Hamas saying its fighters were still engaged in "fierce fighting" inside Israel. The statement by Qassam Brigades said fighting continues in several areas bordering the Gaza strip including Ofakim, Sderot, Yad Mordechai, Kfar Azza, Be'eri, Yatid and Kissufim Hamas militants entered as many as 22 locations outside the Gaza Strip early on Saturday morning, taking captives during the assault. On Sunday, an Israeli military spokesperson said that two hostage situations had been "resolved," but did not say whether all the hostages had been rescued alive. AP/Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israeli military says two hostage situations 'resolved', as fighting continues

children.content: The Israeli military said it was still fighting Hamas incursions in eight places on Sunday morning, according to reports by the AP.
Meanwhile, Reuters reported a statement from Hamas saying its fighters were still engaged in "fierce fighting" inside Israel.
The statement by Qassam Brigades said fighting continues in several areas bordering the Gaza strip including Ofakim, Sderot, Yad Mordechai, Kfar Azza, Be'eri, Yatid and Kissufim
Hamas militants entered as many as 22 locations outside the Gaza Strip early on Saturday morning, taking captives during the assault.
On Sunday, an Israeli military spokesperson said that two hostage situations had been "resolved," but did not say whether all the hostages had been rescued alive.
AP/Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Armed group Hezbollah claimed responsibility for a rocket and artillery attack on the Israeli-occupied Shebaa Farms on Sunday, saying it was "in solidarity" with the Palestinian people. The group said in a written statement cited by Reuters that the attack targeted three posts including a "radar site" in the Shebaa Farms, a slice of land occupied by Israel since 1967 that Lebanon has claimed as its own. As reported earlier, Israel responded on Sunday with artillery fire on southern Lebanon. Israel's military said one its drones struck a Hezbollah post in the area of Har Dov, an area in Shebaa. There have so far been no reports of casualties. Shebaa Farms was captured by Israel from Syria during the 1967 Mideast war, but Lebanon considers it and the nearby Kfar Chouba hills as Lebanese territories. The Golan Heights were annexed by Israel in 1981. Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Hezbollah claims responsibility for attack on Israeli-occupied Shebaa farms

children.content: Armed group Hezbollah claimed responsibility for a rocket and artillery attack on the Israeli-occupied Shebaa Farms on Sunday, saying it was "in solidarity" with the Palestinian people.

The group said in a written statement cited by Reuters that the attack targeted three posts including a "radar site" in the Shebaa Farms, a slice of land occupied by Israel since 1967 that Lebanon has claimed as its own.
As reported earlier, Israel responded on Sunday with artillery fire on southern Lebanon.
Israel's military said one its drones struck a Hezbollah post in the area of Har Dov, an area in Shebaa.
There have so far been no reports of casualties.
Shebaa Farms was captured by Israel from Syria during the 1967 Mideast war, but Lebanon considers it and the nearby Kfar Chouba hills as Lebanese territories.
The Golan Heights were annexed by Israel in 1981.
Reuters

image.altText: A boy next to a burning vehicle.

items.synopsis: Israel is responding to the biggest Hamas attack in years, but the seeds of the unrest were sown decades ago.

title.children: Israel and Hamas 'at war': How did we get here and how is it playing out?

image.altText: Palestinians wave their national flag and celebrate.

items.synopsis: Gaza is one of the most heavily monitored places on earth, constantly watched by satellites and drones and agents on the ground. And yet, Israeli defence and intelligence had no idea Hamas's carefully coordinated assault was coming, writes Adam Harvey.

title.children: How Israel was blindsided by the Hamas attack. The intelligence failure that led to a devastating assault

image.altText: Crying child and father walk down road

items.synopsis: Israel says it is now at war with Hamas, launching air strikes on Gaza and vowing to inflict an "unprecedented price" after dozens of Hamas militants broke out of the blockaded Gaza Strip and into nearby Israeli towns, killing hundreds and abducting others.

title.children: 'We are at war': Israel retaliates with Gaza strikes after Palestinian militants kill hundreds and take hostages

image.altText: A person with an outbreak of shingles

items.synopsis: The risk of developing shingles increases with age. From next month a new vaccine against the virus, tipped to be 90 per cent effective, will be available through the National Immunisation Program for older and immunocompromised Australians.

title.children: Federal government makes new shingles vaccine free for older Australians from November 1

image.altText: A woman wearing a Crows guernsey stands at a podium with media microphones. A group of men stand behind her

items.synopsis: The AFL club still has to complete another round of community consultation and enter an approval process before any building works can commence on its $100 million plans for Thebarton Oval.

title.children: Adelaide Crows step closer to new Thebarton home after $15m boost from SA government

image.altText: A man wearing a broad-brimmed hat stands on a porch with one arm reaching up.

items.synopsis: When Yindjibarndi leader Michael Woodley stood his ground against Andrew Forrest's FMG he had no idea he'd still be fighting for compensation 14 years later. Despite community division and lengthy court battles he's never backed down.

title.children: 'Money, power and influence': One man's fight against Australia's richest man Andrew Forrest

image.altText: Two election placard - one for yes, one for no

items.synopsis: The ABC's poll of the polls now puts Yes at an average of 41.2 per cent, well behind No at 58.8 per cent, Casey Briggs writes.

title.children: How is the Voice polling with less than a week to October 14?

image.altText: Burnt debris is scattered on a bare field near a large gum tree.

items.synopsis: In a statement released through NSW Police, the family of Queensland pilot Peter Nally and his three grandchildren ask for privacy as they "grieve and process this tragedy".

title.children: 'No words to describe the grief': Family of pilot, three children killed in plane crash near Gundaroo ask for privacy

subjects.title: Air and Space Accidents and Incidents

image.altText: A person wearing a dark t-shirt with the words 'vote no to the voice of division'.

items.synopsis: About one fifth of Australia's population live in outer suburbs but this diverse group of voters are more likely to pick No in the upcoming referendum, pollsters predict.

title.children: Support for the Voice to Parliament lacking in Australian outer suburbs, polling suggests

image.altText: A row boat sinking in the ocean with a man clinging on

items.synopsis: After "holding on for dear life" to his flipped rowboat for 14 hours, Tom from Brisbane was rescued. Hear his recount of the ordeal.

title.children: Naked rower going for world record was saved by a cruise ship, heading home to Queensland

image.altText: A spacecrafts solar panel is visible in the foreground, a large grey orange asteroid in the background

items.synopsis: The Psyche mission will travel to an asteroid unlike any we've seen. Its investigations could shed light on how the Solar System and the planets formed.

title.children: This asteroid, worth an estimated $15,600 quadrillion, is the target of a new NASA mission

image.altText: A woman wearing sunglasses, a dark face mask and brown dress makes her way through a press pack with cameras

items.synopsis: Jakarta's police are in the midst of a morality crackdown, raiding porn studios and targeting content creators. But adult performers say it won't do anything to stop Indonesians from accessing porn.

title.children: Siskaeee is Indonesia's best-known adult performer despite a ban on porn and risk of jail time

image.altText: Anthony Albanese standing in front of "VOTE YES" branding as he announces the date of the Voice to Parliament referendum

items.synopsis: Anthony Albanese says the government will "respect the outcome of the referendum" if the Voice vote fails next weekend.

title.children: PM rules out legislating Voice if referendum fails

image.altText: An elderly woman in a red headscarf stands in front of a wall of family photos

items.synopsis: Aunty Ruth Hegarty lived through a cruel chapter in Australian history. Now aged 94, she's approaching the Voice vote with optimism for future generations.

title.children: 'This is truth-telling': At 94, Ruth Hegarty wants to you to hear her story before you vote

image.altText: A woman stands next to a busy street while wearing headphones.

items.synopsis: The "silent walking" trend on TikTok has highlighted how much we rely on audio distractions to get us through the day. But is it a problem?

title.children: 'Me and my thoughts? Sounds horrible': What the 'silent walking' trend says about us

image.altText: Vertical gardens and a fountain.

items.synopsis: Singapore will soon join Dubai to provide travellers with a more efficient immigration clearance as early as 2024 following an update to its Immigration Bill.

title.children: Singapore goes passport-free as experts raise alarms on risks. But it's not the first country to do it

image.altText: Two men sitting at a table, smiling at the camera.

items.synopsis: Before he became Ukraine's commander-in-chief, Volodymyr Zelenskyy was never far from the front lines — these men were there with him, and know a different side to the president.

title.children: The men who know a different side to Volodymyr Zelenskyy

image.altText: A burnt-out shell of a car viewed from the front.

items.synopsis: The gunmen allegedly involved in yesterday's deadly shooting at a shopping centre in Melbourne's north remain on the run, as police reveal the attackers set two getaway cars on fire before fleeing in a third.

title.children: Police say two getaway vehicles set alight after 'frightening' daylight car park killing in Melbourne

image.altText: A photo of a man and a woman with their faces scribbled out.

items.synopsis: A letter from a stranger is all it took to spiral Martin into losing control of his own life. The disability royal commission has made recommendations to reform guardianship legislation, including gag laws that prevent Martin from speaking about his experience.

title.children: Martin isn't allowed to live at home or see his wife. A royal commission wants changes to help others like him

image.altText: Shane van Gisbergen driving during Bathurst 1000.

items.synopsis: Shane van Gisbergen teams up with fellow New Zealander Richie Stanaway to defend his crown with another victory at Mount Panorama. Follow our live blog.

title.children: Van Gisbergen overcomes brake issues to win third Bathurst 1000

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Shane van Gisbergen gets his victory lap, the crowd heralding the champion as he completes the final circuit of the Mount Panorama circuit. For the third time in the last four years, Shane van Gisbergen of Triple Eight Red Bull Racing is Bathurst 1000 champion! A wipe of his brow and a delivers a wry smile from under his helmet. Now he's shredding his tyres to oblivion in a cloud of white smoke. Brodie Kostecki finishes second. Anton de Pasquale gets hits first podium of his career at Bathurst.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Shane van Gisbergen wins Bathurst!

children.content: Shane van Gisbergen gets his victory lap, the crowd heralding the champion as he completes the final circuit of the Mount Panorama circuit.
For the third time in the last four years, Shane van Gisbergen of Triple Eight Red Bull Racing is Bathurst 1000 champion!
A wipe of his brow and a delivers a wry smile from under his helmet.
Now he's shredding his tyres to oblivion in a cloud of white smoke.
Brodie Kostecki finishes second.
Anton de Pasquale gets hits first podium of his career at Bathurst.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Oh my, hang on a minute, get that champagne back on ice. Does Shane van Gisbergen have an issue? "I'm moving the steering and I'm not feeling anything," van Gisbergen says. He is reporting a dead spot in his steering we're hearing now. He's been told that he can back off and still win this race comfortably, but is this car being held together by a wing and a prayer at the moment? 1. Shane van Gisbergen /Richie Stanaway (Triple Eight/Chevrolet): 2. Brodie Kostecki /David Russell (Erebus/Chevrolet): +23.7 3. Anton de Pasquale /Tony D’Alberto (Dick Johnson Racing/Ford): +5.7 4. Chaz Mostert /Lee Holdsworth (Walkinshaw Andretti United/Ford): +10.2 5. David Reynolds /Garth Tander (Grove/Ford): +5.4
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Lap 152: Shane van Gisbergen complains of poor steering!

children.content: Oh my, hang on a minute, get that champagne back on ice.
Does Shane van Gisbergen have an issue?
"I'm moving the steering and I'm not feeling anything," van Gisbergen says.
He is reporting a dead spot in his steering we're hearing now.
He's been told that he can back off and still win this race comfortably, but is this car being held together by a wing and a prayer at the moment?
Shane van Gisbergen
/Richie Stanaway
(Triple Eight/Chevrolet):
Brodie Kostecki
/David Russell
(Erebus/Chevrolet): +23.7
(Getty Images)
Anton de Pasquale
/Tony D’Alberto
(Dick Johnson Racing/Ford): +5.7
Chaz Mostert
/Lee Holdsworth (Walkinshaw Andretti United/Ford): +10.2
David Reynolds
/Garth Tander (Grove/Ford): +5.4

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: He's going incredibly slowly and has dived straight into the pits! Not only that, he's having to go straight into the garage - not even the pit box - so a major issue for the Red Bull number 88 car. It's a gear box problem! Well that's him out of contention - that's a disaster for Broc Feeney - who is covering his eyes in the car, devastated at seeing his first Bathurst podium slip away.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Broc Feeney has an issue!

children.content: He's going incredibly slowly and has dived straight into the pits!
Not only that, he's having to go straight into the garage - not even the pit box - so a major issue for the Red Bull number 88 car.
It's a gear box problem!
Well that's him out of contention - that's a disaster for Broc Feeney - who is covering his eyes in the car, devastated at seeing his first Bathurst podium slip away.
(Fox Sports)

image.altText: Artist's impression of an asteroid collision with Earth.

items.synopsis: In 2020, Oxford philosopher Toby Ord put the chances of "existential catastrophe" for our species during the next century at one in six. But does it really stack up, asks Steven Stern.

title.children: Is there really a 1 in 6 chance of human extinction this century?

items.synopsis: Australian law enforcement has started solving missing persons and unidentified remains cases using official police access to private genealogy databases, which combined, hold the DNA records of millions of people around the world.

title.children: It's being called the biggest game-changer in forensic investigations since DNA testing

image.altText: Tevita Ikanivere and Ilaisa Droasese clap

items.synopsis: The Rugby World Cup has been an unmitigated disaster for the Wallabies but they can still qualify for the quarterfinals. Here's how.

title.children: How the Wallabies can qualify for the World Cup quarterfinals

image.altText: A man holds a bundle of raw hemp fire.

items.synopsis: Hemp is one of the toughest plants on the planet and its potential uses range from bulletproof vests in the US to waterproof flooring for housing and other robust building products in Australia.

title.children: The bulletproof plant undergoing high-velocity growth

image.altText: Sun setting over Indian Ocean

items.synopsis: Climate researchers at the Bureau of Meteorology hope a new system will prevent situations where some agencies are declaring an El Niño event and others aren't.

title.children: Weather scientists worry fast-warming oceans have warped BoM's El Niño index

image.altText: a group of men stand around on rubble

items.synopsis: A magnitude-6.3 earthquake followed by strong aftershocks kills more than 2,000 people in Afghanistan's west, according to a Taliban spokesman, after hundreds of civilians were buried under rubble.

title.children: Powerful earthquake and aftershocks kill more than 2,000 people in western Afghanistan

image.altText: Lady in costume made out of ghost nets

items.synopsis: From striking art installations to one-of-a-kind costumes, two designers are transforming marine debris into "beautiful things" that highlight a scourge that plagues our beaches.

title.children: Ghost nets come alive in a sardine-packed fashion spectacular

image.altText: An Essendon AFLW player holds the ball in her right hand in front of a Geelong opponent.

items.synopsis: Essendon pulls off a sensational come-from-behind win over Geelong, triumphing by 10 points in Warrnambool as Maddy Prespakis earns bragging rights over younger sister Georgie.

title.children: Bombers conquer Cats to climb inside AFLW top eight

image.altText: An F1 driver, out of his car, surrounded by pit in the pit, being congratulated

items.synopsis: Max Verstappen's place among the best drivers in Formula 1's history has been confirmed with a third drivers' championship.

title.children: Oscar Piastri gets first F1 victory, Verstappen wins world championship
